importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication indicates the current status of the diplomatic and aviation developments between China and India, reflecting the timing of the resumption of flights as part of a broader diplomatic thaw.
The date marks when the public announcement of resuming flights was made, signaling a recent development in bilateral relations.
This date coincides with the broader context of renewed diplomatic engagement between India and China, including high-level meetings and trade discussions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Direct flights between India and China were suspended during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, marking a significant break in air connectivity that lasted until the recent resumption.
The five-year freeze in direct flights from 2020 to 2025 reflects a period of strained relations due to border clashes and geopolitical tensions, now ending with a diplomatic revival.

keyTakeAways: China Eastern Airlines will resume Shanghai-Delhi flights starting November 9, 2025, after a five-year suspension.
The resumption of flights is part of a broader diplomatic thaw between India and China, triggered by shared concerns over U.S. trade policies.
The flights will operate three times a week—on Wednesdays, Saturdays, and Sundays—on China Eastern Airlines’ online platform.
This revival follows Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s first visit to China in over seven years, during which trade and border issues were discussed.
India’s largest carrier, IndiGo, previously announced daily nonstop flights between Kolkata and Guangzhou, prompting Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport to encourage more direct routes.
The suspension of direct flights began during the pandemic and was further extended due to deadly border clashes in 2020 that killed four Chinese and 20 Indian soldiers.
The diplomatic shift is occurring amid increasingly aggressive U.S. trade policies, including a 50% tariff on Indian imports and a proposed 100% tariff on China and India by the U.S. government.

namedEntities.name: China Eastern Airlines
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China Eastern Airlines is central to the article as the airline that is resuming direct flights to India after a five-year freeze, symbolizing a revival of bilateral air travel and economic ties.

namedEntities.name: India
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: India is a key partner in the diplomatic and economic revival, with renewed flights and trade discussions reflecting improved relations after years of tension.

namedEntities.name: Shanghai
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Shanghai is the origin point of the resumed flights, highlighting China’s key economic and commercial hubs as centers of international connectivity.

namedEntities.name: Delhi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Delhi is the destination of the resumed flights, signifying a return of direct air links between major Indian and Chinese urban centers.

namedEntities.name: Narendra Modi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Modi’s visit to China marks a pivotal moment in the diplomatic thaw, directly influencing the decision to restart flights and discuss trade issues.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global political and economic power
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The U.S. trade policies, particularly the tariffs on India and China, are a key external factor influencing the diplomatic and economic dynamics between India and China.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s aggressive trade policies, including proposed 100% tariffs on China and India, are a significant backdrop to the India-China diplomatic revival, suggesting a geopolitical realignment in response to U.S. pressure.

namedEntities.name: Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A regional security and political bloc
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The summit meeting between India and China within the SCO framework provided a formal setting for diplomatic engagement, reinforcing the context of the flight resumption.

namedEntities.name: IndiGo
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: IndiGo’s announcement of Kolkata-Guangzhou flights shows India’s proactive effort to expand air connectivity with China, contributing to the broader trend of resuming direct air links.

namedEntities.name: Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major international airport in China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This airport has publicly supported the opening of new international routes, indicating state-level encouragement of expanded air travel between India and China.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China Eastern Airlines is resuming direct flights from Shanghai to Delhi, beginning November 9, 2025, after a five-year hiatus caused by border clashes and the pandemic. The move follows a diplomatic thaw between India and China, marked by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s first visit to China in over seven years, and is occurring amid increasing U.S. trade tensions, including proposed high tariffs on Indian and Chinese goods. The restoration of flights signals a renewed commitment to economic and commercial ties, with India’s IndiGo also announcing flights between Kolkata and Guangzhou, and China’s Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport encouraging further route development. The resumption reflects a broader geopolitical shift where regional powers are seeking alternatives to U.S. trade pressure.
title: China Eastern Airlines to resume flights to India after five-year freeze
